Notes on Information Propagation in Noisy Multichannel Data Models: Insights into Sensor Selection and Fusion in Multimodal Biomedical Applications

Reza Sameni R. Sameni is with the Department of Biomedical Informatics, Emory University (email: rsameni@dbmi.emory.edu).
(December 2023)
Abstract

Multimodality and multichannel monitoring have become increasingly popular and accessible in engineering, Internet of Things, wearable devices, and biomedical applications. In these contexts, given the diverse and complex nature of data modalities, the relevance of sensor fusion and sensor selection is heightened. In this note, we study the problem of channel/modality selection and fusion from an information theoretical perspective, focusing on linear and nonlinear signal mixtures corrupted by additive Gaussian noise. We revisit and extend well-known properties of linear noisy data models in estimation and information theory, providing practical insights that assist in the decision-making process between channel (modality) selection and fusion. Using the notion of multichannel signal-to-noise ratio, we derive conditions under which, selection or fusion of multimodal/multichannel data can be beneficial or redundant. This contributes to a better understanding of how to optimize sensor fusion and selection from a theoretical standpoint, aiming to enhance multimodal/multichannel system design, especially for biomedical multichannel/multimodal applications.

1 Introduction

The problem of modality/channel selection has vast applications in biomedical research. This includes lead selection and fusion for noninvasive fetal [6] and adult [10, 11] electrocardiography; it also relates to the issue of multimodal cardiac monitoring [7]. Multimodal and multichannel data processing is motivated by the assumption that each modality conveys complementary information, leading to improved overall performance compared to single modality (or single-channel) approaches in terms of detection rate, estimation performance, classification rate, etc. However, despite expectations, some studies have shown that this assumption is not always accurate. When the data model is inaccurate, depending on the noise level and the correlations between the source signals and noises, selecting a particular modality (or channel) can sometimes be more effective than combining them. It has been shown that under imperfect data models, adding dimensions and modalities can actually degrade overall performance [3, 2]. This phenomenon has been theoretically verified from an information and estimation theoretical perspective and is applicable even with as few as two data channels or modalities.

In this note, we aim to expand on these findings by further examining the estimation theoretical properties of multichannel/multimodal linear and nonlinear source-sensor mixtures corrupted by additive Gaussian noise. Using standard estimation schemes, including least squares, maximum likelihood and Bayesian estimation, we shown that the signal-to-noise-ratio (SNR) matrix [9] — a generalization of the notion of scalar SNR — plays a significant role in channel fusion and selection in all estimation schemes.

3 Source estimation

Throughout the note, the objective is to estimate 𝒔𝒔\bm{s}bold_italic_s. We will investigate three levels of prior knowledge:

  1. 1.

    Data model-only, using a least squares formulation;

  2. 2.

    Gaussian noise model presumption using a maximum likelihood framework; and

  3. 3.

    The fully Bayesian framework, in which the data-model, noise distribution and the source distribution are all presumed.

We will see that from top to bottom, while the actual measurements 𝒙𝒙\bm{x}bold_italic_x are the same, we gain additional information through priors presumptions on the source and noise.

3.1 Least squares

Considering the data model in (1), without any additional priors on the source or noise distributions, we have limited options to estimate the source vector. In this case, the least squares (LS) and weighted least squares (WLS) are the most popular:

𝒔^WLS=Δarg⁢min𝒔∥𝒙−𝐀𝒔∥𝐖=arg⁢min𝒔(𝒙−𝐀𝒔)T𝐖(𝒙−𝐀𝒔)\hat{\bm{s}}_{\text{WLS}}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\operatorname*{% arg\,min}_{\bm{s}}{\|\bm{x}-\mathbf{A}\bm{s}\|_{\mathbf{W}}}=\operatorname*{% arg\,min}_{\bm{s}}{(\bm{x}-\mathbf{A}\bm{s})^{T}\mathbf{W}(\bm{x}-\mathbf{A}% \bm{s})}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_s end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT WLS end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Δ end_ARG end_RELOP start_OPERATOR roman_arg roman_min end_OPERATOR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ bold_italic_x - bold_A bold_italic_s ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = start_OPERATOR roman_arg roman_min end_OPERATOR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x - bold_A bold_italic_s ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_W ( bold_italic_x - bold_A bold_italic_s ) (3)

where 𝐖∈ℝn×n𝐖superscriptℝ𝑛𝑛\mathbf{W}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times n}bold_W ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n × italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a positive semi-definite matrix that to penalize the sample-wise measurement errors. The solution to the WLS problem is

𝒔^WLS=(𝐀T⁢𝐖𝐀)−1⁢𝐀T⁢𝐖⁢𝒙subscript^𝒔WLSsuperscriptsuperscript𝐀𝑇𝐖𝐀1superscript𝐀𝑇𝐖𝒙\hat{\bm{s}}_{\text{WLS}}=(\mathbf{A}^{T}\mathbf{W}\mathbf{A})^{-1}\mathbf{A}^% {T}\mathbf{W}\bm{x}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_s end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT WLS end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( bold_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_WA ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_W bold_italic_x (4)

Setting 𝐖=𝐈𝐖𝐈\mathbf{W}=\mathbf{I}bold_W = bold_I simplifies to the standard least squares scheme, which handles all measurements with the same weight. Alternatively, if the measurement noise 𝒗𝒗\bm{v}bold_italic_v is known to be zero-mean with covariance 𝚺𝚺\bm{\Sigma}bold_Σ (not necessarily Gaussian), we can intuitively set 𝐖=𝚺−1𝐖superscript𝚺1\mathbf{W}=\bm{\Sigma}^{-1}bold_W = bold_Σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This choice results in

𝒔^WLS=(𝐀T⁢𝚺−1⁢𝐀)−1⁢𝐀T⁢𝚺−1⁢𝒙subscript^𝒔WLSsuperscriptsuperscript𝐀𝑇superscript𝚺1𝐀1superscript𝐀𝑇superscript𝚺1𝒙\hat{\bm{s}}_{\text{WLS}}=(\mathbf{A}^{T}\bm{\Sigma}^{-1}\mathbf{A})^{-1}% \mathbf{A}^{T}\bm{\Sigma}^{-1}\bm{x}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_s end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT WLS end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( bold_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_Σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_A ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_Σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x (5)

Importantly, this is only a heuristic choice and the LS framework by itself does not justify this selection, beyond intuition, i.e., decorrelating the observation noises and down-weighting the noisier measurements.

3.1.1 Weighted least squares estimation quality

The WLS estimator can be evaluated in terms of its bias and error covariance. The WLS solution in (5) is an unbiased estimate of the deterministic or stochastic source vector 𝒔𝒔\bm{s}bold_italic_s. In other words, 𝔼⁢{𝒔^WLS}=𝒔𝔼subscript^𝒔WLS𝒔\mathbb{E}\{\hat{\bm{s}}_{\text{WLS}}\}=\bm{s}blackboard_E { over^ start_ARG bold_italic_s end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT WLS end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } = bold_italic_s, leading to the error covariance matrix:

𝐂WLS=Δ𝔼⁢{(𝒔−𝒔^WLS)⁢(𝒔−𝒔^WLS)T}=(𝐀T⁢𝚺−1⁢𝐀)−1superscriptΔsubscript𝐂WLS𝔼𝒔subscript^𝒔WLSsuperscript𝒔subscript^𝒔WLS𝑇superscriptsuperscript𝐀𝑇superscript𝚺1𝐀1\mathbf{C}_{\text{WLS}}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\mathbb{E}\{(\bm{s}% -\hat{\bm{s}}_{\text{WLS}})(\bm{s}-\hat{\bm{s}}_{\text{WLS}})^{T}\}=(\mathbf{A% }^{T}\bm{\Sigma}^{-1}\mathbf{A})^{-1}bold_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT WLS end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Δ end_ARG end_RELOP blackboard_E { ( bold_italic_s - over^ start_ARG bold_italic_s end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT WLS end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( bold_italic_s - over^ start_ARG bold_italic_s end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT WLS end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } = ( bold_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_Σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_A ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (6)

Accordingly, the estimation quality depends only on the matrix:

𝚜𝚗𝚛=Δ𝐀T⁢𝚺−1⁢𝐀superscriptΔ𝚜𝚗𝚛superscript𝐀𝑇superscript𝚺1𝐀\textbf{{snr}}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\mathbf{A}^{T}\bm{\Sigma}^{-% 1}\mathbf{A}snr start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Δ end_ARG end_RELOP bold_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_Σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_A (7)

This matrix is recognized in the literature as the signal to noise ratio (SNR) matrix [9], representing a multichannel extension of the conventional scalar SNR. To summarize, up to this point, we have only made two assumptions: i) the data model in (1), and ii) a zero-mean noise vector 𝒗𝒗\bm{v}bold_italic_v with covariance matrix 𝚺𝚺\bm{\Sigma}bold_Σ and an arbitrary distribution.

3.2 Maximum likelihood

The LS formulation did not require (and benefit from) any assumptions on the distributions of the source and noise vectors. If any such priors are available, one may use the maximum likelihood (ML) framework, which seeks:

𝒔^ML⁢(𝒙)=Δarg⁢max𝒔⁡f𝑿|𝑺⁢(𝒙|𝒔)superscriptΔsubscript^𝒔ML𝒙subscriptargmax𝒔subscript𝑓conditional𝑿𝑺conditional𝒙𝒔\hat{\bm{s}}_{\text{ML}}(\bm{x})\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}% \operatorname*{arg\,max}_{\bm{s}}{f_{\bm{X}|\bm{S}}(\bm{x}|\bm{s})}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_s end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ML end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x ) start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Δ end_ARG end_RELOP start_OPERATOR roman_arg roman_max end_OPERATOR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_X | bold_italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x | bold_italic_s ) (8)

which reads: “find the source vector that maximizes the probability of observing a given 𝐱𝐱\bm{x}bold_italic_x.” To answer this question, the noise distribution is required, while the source 𝒔𝒔\bm{s}bold_italic_s can be deterministic or have an arbitrary stochastic distribution. which is the same solution obtained from the intuitive WLS formulation.

3.2.1 Maximum likelihood estimation quality

Inserting the ML estimator derived in (9) into the data model (1), we find:

which is the inverse of the SNR matrix defined in (7).

3.3 Bayesian estimation framework

Bayesian estimation is the most complete of the three frameworks, which benefits from the data model, noise and source distributions. Bayesian estimation generally seeks

𝒔^bys=arg⁢min𝒔^⁡𝔼⁢{c⁢(𝒔,𝒔^)}subscript^𝒔byssubscriptargmin^𝒔𝔼𝑐𝒔^𝒔\hat{\bm{s}}_{\text{bys}}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\hat{\bm{s}}}\mathbb{E}\{c% (\bm{s},\hat{\bm{s}})\}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_s end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bys end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = start_OPERATOR roman_arg roman_min end_OPERATOR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_italic_s end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E { italic_c ( bold_italic_s , over^ start_ARG bold_italic_s end_ARG ) } (12)

where the expectation is taken over the joint distribution f𝑿,𝑺⁢(𝒙,𝒔)subscript𝑓𝑿𝑺𝒙𝒔f_{\bm{X},\bm{S}}(\bm{x},\bm{s})italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_X , bold_italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_s ), and c⁢(𝒔,𝒔^)𝑐𝒔^𝒔c(\bm{s},\hat{\bm{s}})italic_c ( bold_italic_s , over^ start_ARG bold_italic_s end_ARG ) is a non-negative cost of error typically chosen to be in the form of c⁢(𝒔,𝒔^)=L⁢(|𝒔−𝒔^|)𝑐𝒔^𝒔𝐿𝒔^𝒔c(\bm{s},\hat{\bm{s}})=L(|\bm{s}-\hat{\bm{s}}|)italic_c ( bold_italic_s , over^ start_ARG bold_italic_s end_ARG ) = italic_L ( | bold_italic_s - over^ start_ARG bold_italic_s end_ARG | ) fulfilling L⁢(0)=0𝐿00L(0)=0italic_L ( 0 ) = 0 [13].

The minimum mean square error (MMSE) estimator is a special case for the Bayesian estimator (12), which uses a quadratic error function c⁢(𝒔,𝒔^)=Δ(𝒔−𝒔^)T⁢𝐌⁢(𝒔−𝒔^)superscriptΔ𝑐𝒔^𝒔superscript𝒔^𝒔𝑇𝐌𝒔^𝒔c(\bm{s},\hat{\bm{s}})\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}(\bm{s}-\hat{\bm{s}}% )^{T}\mathbf{M}(\bm{s}-\hat{\bm{s}})italic_c ( bold_italic_s , over^ start_ARG bold_italic_s end_ARG ) start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Δ end_ARG end_RELOP ( bold_italic_s - over^ start_ARG bold_italic_s end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_M ( bold_italic_s - over^ start_ARG bold_italic_s end_ARG ), where 𝐌𝐌\mathbf{M}bold_M is an arbitrary positive semi-definite matrix. This choice leads to the MMSE estimator:

also known as the conditional mean. More generally, under a set of sufficient conditions — originally derived by S. Sherman — 𝒔^mmsesubscript^𝒔mmse\hat{\bm{s}}_{\text{mmse}}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_s end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT mmse end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is also the optimal estimator for any other symmetric convex error cost function c⁢(𝒔,𝒔^)𝑐𝒔^𝒔c(\bm{s},\hat{\bm{s}})italic_c ( bold_italic_s , over^ start_ARG bold_italic_s end_ARG ) [13, Ch. 2.4].

3.3.1 The MMSE estimation quality

As noted above, the MMSE estimator is unbiased and the error covariance matrix is:

3.4 The Cramér Rao lower bound

It is insightful to review the Cramér Rao lower bound (CRLB) for the data model (1), in the Bayesian and maximum likelihood frameworks.

3.4.1 The CRLB for deterministic (fixed) sources

Supposing that 𝒔^⁢(𝒙)^𝒔𝒙\hat{\bm{s}}(\bm{x})over^ start_ARG bold_italic_s end_ARG ( bold_italic_x ) is an unbiased estimator of the unknown vector 𝒔𝒔\bm{s}bold_italic_s (deterministic or stochastic but fixed), there exists a minimum on the covariance of the estimation error [13, pp. 79–80]. Accordingly111Note that the matrix inequality 𝐀⪰𝐁succeeds-or-equals𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A}\succeq\mathbf{B}bold_A ⪰ bold_B, used in (15), denotes that 𝐀−𝐁𝐀𝐁\mathbf{A}-\mathbf{B}bold_A - bold_B is positive semi-definite.,

𝔼𝒙⁢{[𝒔−𝒔^⁢(𝒙)]⁢[𝒔−𝒔^⁢(𝒙)]T}⪰𝐉𝒙|𝒔−1succeeds-or-equalssubscript𝔼𝒙delimited-[]𝒔^𝒔𝒙superscriptdelimited-[]𝒔^𝒔𝒙𝑇superscriptsubscript𝐉conditional𝒙𝒔1\mathbb{E}_{\bm{x}}\{[\bm{s}-\hat{\bm{s}}(\bm{x})][\bm{s}-\hat{\bm{s}}(\bm{x})% ]^{T}\}\succeq\mathbf{J}_{\bm{x}|\bm{s}}^{-1}blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { [ bold_italic_s - over^ start_ARG bold_italic_s end_ARG ( bold_italic_x ) ] [ bold_italic_s - over^ start_ARG bold_italic_s end_ARG ( bold_italic_x ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ⪰ bold_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x | bold_italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (15)

where the expectation is over the observations 𝒙𝒙\bm{x}bold_italic_x and 𝐉𝒙|𝒔subscript𝐉conditional𝒙𝒔\mathbf{J}_{\bm{x}|\bm{s}}bold_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x | bold_italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (which is generally a function of 𝒔𝒔\bm{s}bold_italic_s) is the Fisher information matrix with the following entries:

[𝐉𝒙|𝒔]k⁢l=Δ𝔼𝒙⁢{∂∂sk⁢log⁡f𝑿|𝑺⁢(𝒙|𝒔)⁢∂∂sl⁢log⁡f𝑿|𝑺⁢(𝒙|𝒔)}=−𝔼𝒙⁢{∂2∂sk⁢sl⁢log⁡f𝑿|𝑺⁢(𝒙|𝒔)}superscriptΔsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐉conditional𝒙𝒔𝑘𝑙subscript𝔼𝒙subscript𝑠𝑘subscript𝑓conditional𝑿𝑺conditional𝒙𝒔subscript𝑠𝑙subscript𝑓conditional𝑿𝑺conditional𝒙𝒔subscript𝔼𝒙superscript2subscript𝑠𝑘subscript𝑠𝑙subscript𝑓conditional𝑿𝑺conditional𝒙𝒔[\mathbf{J}_{\bm{x}|\bm{s}}]_{kl}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\mathbb{E% }_{\bm{x}}\{\frac{\partial}{\partial s_{k}}\log f_{\bm{X}|\bm{S}}(\bm{x}|\bm{s% })\frac{\partial}{\partial s_{l}}\log f_{\bm{X}|\bm{S}}(\bm{x}|\bm{s})\}=-% \mathbb{E}_{\bm{x}}\{\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial s_{k}s_{l}}\log f_{\bm{X}|% \bm{S}}(\bm{x}|\bm{s})\}[ bold_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x | bold_italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Δ end_ARG end_RELOP blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { divide start_ARG ∂ end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG roman_log italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_X | bold_italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x | bold_italic_s ) divide start_ARG ∂ end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG roman_log italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_X | bold_italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x | bold_italic_s ) } = - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { divide start_ARG ∂ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG roman_log italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_X | bold_italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x | bold_italic_s ) } (16)

An unbiased estimator that reaches the CRLB is called an efficient estimator, and whenever an efficient estimator exists, it is the ML estimator.

We can show that for the data model defined in (1) and a Gaussian noise:

𝐉𝒙|𝒔=𝐀T⁢𝚺−1⁢𝐀=𝚜𝚗𝚛subscript𝐉conditional𝒙𝒔superscript𝐀𝑇superscript𝚺1𝐀𝚜𝚗𝚛\mathbf{J}_{\bm{x}|\bm{s}}=\mathbf{A}^{T}\bm{\Sigma}^{-1}\mathbf{A}=\textbf{{% snr}}bold_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x | bold_italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_Σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_A = snr (17)

In other words, for the data model of interest, the SNR matrix is equal to the Fisher information matrix and the ML estimate is an efficient estimator (compare (11) with (17)).

It should be noted that the ML estimator does not necessarily exist, for instance in the cases that there is no information in the observations regarding an entry (or some entries) of the source vector. In the linear model, a necessary condition for the existence of the ML estimate is that the observation vector length be equal to or greater than the source vector length (otherwise the Fisher information matrix is singular).

3.5 Fisher information for two set of sensors

Let us now expand the previous results to two sets of sensors from the same vector source:

Herein, we name these matrices synergic information matrices, as they convey the excess information carried by the joint observations, as compared to using any of the observation sets individually. Apparently, since 𝐒𝒙,𝒚𝒙superscriptsubscript𝐒𝒙𝒚𝒙\mathbf{S}_{\bm{x},\bm{y}}^{\bm{x}}bold_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x , bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and 𝐒𝒙,𝒚𝒚superscriptsubscript𝐒𝒙𝒚𝒚\mathbf{S}_{\bm{x},\bm{y}}^{\bm{y}}bold_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x , bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are positive definite matrices, the Fisher information matrix of the joint measurements is always greater than or equal to the individual Fisher information matrices, and the CRLB is equal or lower when we use both modalities (observation sets), as compared to any of the two modalities. The boundary case is when the multiplicand factors in (35) are zero, which makes one of the modalities redundant. This case is only achievable with correlated noises 𝒗𝒗\bm{v}bold_italic_v and 𝒖𝒖\bm{u}bold_italic_u.

3.5.2 Prewhitening

A more simplified representation of the synergy between the sensor sets can be obtained by applying prewhitening on the two set of observations. This practically means that perfect noise rejection can be obtained by merging the two sensor sets (modalities), when the noises are fully correlated.

3.5.3 Optimal multi-sensor set cross-correlation

Another question concerns the optimal cross correlation between the noises of the two modalities that would result in the best synergy between the two modalities. Optimizing (37) with respect to the cross correlation function can be performed by maximizing:

otherwise, there exist one or more entries of 𝒔𝒔\bm{s}bold_italic_s for which using 𝒚~~𝒚\tilde{\bm{y}}over~ start_ARG bold_italic_y end_ARG would result in smaller or equal MMSE; • Modality fusion applications: in terms of Fisher information, using both observations is always preferred over (or is at least as good as), using any single observation; • Weakly correlated noise: if 𝝆=𝟎𝝆0\bm{\rho}=\mathbf{0}bold_italic_ρ = bold_0, the Fisher information of the two modalities are additive (𝐀~T⁢𝐀~+𝐁~T⁢𝐁~superscript~𝐀𝑇~𝐀superscript~𝐁𝑇~𝐁\tilde{\mathbf{A}}^{T}\tilde{\mathbf{A}}+\tilde{\mathbf{B}}^{T}\tilde{\mathbf{% B}}over~ start_ARG bold_A end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG bold_A end_ARG + over~ start_ARG bold_B end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG bold_B end_ARG); • Strongly correlated noise: if 𝝆𝝆\bm{\rho}bold_italic_ρ approaches a unitary matrix (𝝆⁢𝝆T→𝐈→𝝆superscript𝝆𝑇𝐈\bm{\rho}\bm{\rho}^{T}\rightarrow\mathbf{I}bold_italic_ρ bold_italic_ρ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → bold_I) and 𝐀~≠𝝆⁢𝐁~~𝐀𝝆~𝐁\tilde{\mathbf{A}}\neq\bm{\rho}\tilde{\mathbf{B}}over~ start_ARG bold_A end_ARG ≠ bold_italic_ρ over~ start_ARG bold_B end_ARG and 𝐁~≠𝝆T⁢𝐀~~𝐁superscript𝝆𝑇~𝐀\tilde{\mathbf{B}}\neq\bm{\rho}^{T}\tilde{\mathbf{A}}over~ start_ARG bold_B end_ARG ≠ bold_italic_ρ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG bold_A end_ARG, the Fisher information approaches infinity (the MMSE attains its minimum); • Modality redundancy: if 𝐁~=𝝆T⁢𝐀~~𝐁superscript𝝆𝑇~𝐀\tilde{\mathbf{B}}=\bm{\rho}^{T}\tilde{\mathbf{A}}over~ start_ARG bold_B end_ARG = bold_italic_ρ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG bold_A end_ARG, then 𝒚~~𝒚\tilde{\bm{y}}over~ start_ARG bold_italic_y end_ARG is redundant and the Fisher information is 𝐀~T⁢𝐀~superscript~𝐀𝑇~𝐀\tilde{\mathbf{A}}^{T}\tilde{\mathbf{A}}over~ start_ARG bold_A end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG bold_A end_ARG, and if 𝐀~=𝝆⁢𝐁~~𝐀𝝆~𝐁\tilde{\mathbf{A}}=\bm{\rho}\tilde{\mathbf{B}}over~ start_ARG bold_A end_ARG = bold_italic_ρ over~ start_ARG bold_B end_ARG, then 𝒙~~𝒙\tilde{\bm{x}}over~ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG is redundant and the Fisher information is 𝐁~T⁢𝐁~superscript~𝐁𝑇~𝐁\tilde{\mathbf{B}}^{T}\tilde{\mathbf{B}}over~ start_ARG bold_B end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG bold_B end_ARG; • Admissibility: (𝐈−𝝆T⁢𝝆)≻𝟎succeeds𝐈superscript𝝆𝑇𝝆0(\mathbf{I}-\bm{\rho}^{T}\bm{\rho})\succ\mathbf{0}( bold_I - bold_italic_ρ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_ρ ) ≻ bold_0 and |λ⁢(𝝆⁢𝝆T)|<1𝜆𝝆superscript𝝆𝑇1|\lambda(\bm{\rho}\bm{\rho}^{T})|<1| italic_λ ( bold_italic_ρ bold_italic_ρ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) | < 1; hence, only the modality with a weaker SNR may be redundant (the smaller between |𝐀~T⁢𝐀~|superscript~𝐀𝑇~𝐀|\tilde{\mathbf{A}}^{T}\tilde{\mathbf{A}}|| over~ start_ARG bold_A end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG bold_A end_ARG | and |𝐁~T⁢𝐁~|superscript~𝐁𝑇~𝐁|\tilde{\mathbf{B}}^{T}\tilde{\mathbf{B}}|| over~ start_ARG bold_B end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG bold_B end_ARG |)

Some of the special two scalar sensor cases studied in [2] are special cases of the above lemma.

3.6 Optimal secondary sensor configuration

Another interesting scenario is when we have already a set of (pre-whitened) sensors 𝒙~=𝐀~⁢𝒔+𝒗~~𝒙~𝐀𝒔~𝒗\tilde{\bm{x}}=\tilde{\mathbf{A}}\bm{s}+\tilde{\bm{v}}over~ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG = over~ start_ARG bold_A end_ARG bold_italic_s + over~ start_ARG bold_italic_v end_ARG and would like to set up a secondary set of sensors 𝒚~=𝐁~⁢𝒔+𝒖~~𝒚~𝐁𝒔~𝒖\tilde{\bm{y}}=\tilde{\mathbf{B}}\bm{s}+\tilde{\bm{u}}over~ start_ARG bold_italic_y end_ARG = over~ start_ARG bold_B end_ARG bold_italic_s + over~ start_ARG bold_italic_u end_ARG, with maximum synergy with the first group of sensors. In other words, we seek the secondary sensor configuration with minimal redundancy with the first set. The answer to this problem is nontrivial. It has recently gained notable attention in the blind source separation literature [5, 6]. Most recently, a game theoretical approach based on SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) values has been proposed [8].

The hereby proposed information-based approach can provide an alternative perspective to this nontrivial problem. Considering that the first sensor set has been readily fixed, the problem can be formulated as a matrix design problem for the secondary mixing matrix 𝐁~~𝐁\tilde{\mathbf{B}}over~ start_ARG bold_B end_ARG. Assuming that the secondary set of sensors has a bounded SNR, say tr⁡(𝐁T~⁢𝐁~)≤ptr~superscript𝐁𝑇~𝐁𝑝\operatorname{tr}(\tilde{\mathbf{B}^{T}}\tilde{\mathbf{B}})\leq proman_tr ( over~ start_ARG bold_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG over~ start_ARG bold_B end_ARG ) ≤ italic_p, the problem can be formulated as follows:

𝐁~*=arg⁢max𝐁~⁡[tr⁡(𝐉𝒙,𝒚)−λ⁢tr⁡(𝐁~T⁢𝐁~)]superscript~𝐁subscriptargmax~𝐁trsubscript𝐉𝒙𝒚𝜆trsuperscript~𝐁𝑇~𝐁\tilde{\mathbf{B}}^{*}=\operatorname*{arg\,max}_{\tilde{\mathbf{B}}}[% \operatorname{tr}(\mathbf{J}_{\bm{x},\bm{y}})-\lambda\operatorname{tr}(\tilde{% \mathbf{B}}^{T}\tilde{\mathbf{B}})]over~ start_ARG bold_B end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = start_OPERATOR roman_arg roman_max end_OPERATOR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG bold_B end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_tr ( bold_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x , bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_λ roman_tr ( over~ start_ARG bold_B end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG bold_B end_ARG ) ] (41)

for some λ≥0𝜆0\lambda\geq 0italic_λ ≥ 0, which by differentiation with respect to 𝐁~~𝐁\tilde{\mathbf{B}}over~ start_ARG bold_B end_ARG results in

𝐁~*=[𝐈−λ⁢(𝐈−𝝆T⁢𝝆)]−1⁢𝝆T⁢𝐀~superscript~𝐁superscriptdelimited-[]𝐈𝜆𝐈superscript𝝆𝑇𝝆1superscript𝝆𝑇~𝐀\tilde{\mathbf{B}}^{*}=[\mathbf{I}-\lambda(\mathbf{I}-\bm{\rho}^{T}\bm{\rho})]% ^{-1}\bm{\rho}^{T}\tilde{\mathbf{A}}over~ start_ARG bold_B end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ bold_I - italic_λ ( bold_I - bold_italic_ρ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_ρ ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_ρ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG bold_A end_ARG (42)

and the Lagrange multiplier λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ is selected such that the SNR constraint tr⁡(𝐁T~⁢𝐁~)≤ptr~superscript𝐁𝑇~𝐁𝑝\operatorname{tr}(\tilde{\mathbf{B}^{T}}\tilde{\mathbf{B}})\leq proman_tr ( over~ start_ARG bold_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG over~ start_ARG bold_B end_ARG ) ≤ italic_p is fulfilled, or remains as a design parameter, if p𝑝pitalic_p is unknown444Finding λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ for a known p𝑝pitalic_p can be achieved by performing the SVD 𝝆=𝐔⁢𝚺⁢𝐕T𝝆𝐔𝚺superscript𝐕𝑇\bm{\rho}=\mathbf{U}\bm{\Sigma}\mathbf{V}^{T}bold_italic_ρ = bold_U bold_Σ bold_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This equation can be solved by root locus approaches common in linear control theory. . The optimal secondary configuration, clearly depends on the primary configuration, the correlation between the noises of both configurations, and the SNR “budget”. Equation (42) can be further simplified using the singular value decomposition of 𝝆𝝆\bm{\rho}bold_italic_ρ.

𝐉𝒙|𝒔=𝔼𝒔{∇𝐡(𝒔)𝚺−1∇𝐡(𝒔)T}\mathbf{J}_{\bm{x}|\bm{s}}=\mathbb{E}_{\bm{s}}\{\bm{\nabla}_{\mathbf{h}}(\bm{s% })\bm{\Sigma}^{-1}\bm{\nabla}_{\mathbf{h}}(\bm{s})^{T}\}bold_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x | bold_italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { bold_∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_s ) bold_Σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_s ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } (47)

which is the nonlinear extension of the Fisher information derived in (17). Similarly, we obtain the following information matrix for the case in which the source vector 𝒔𝒔\bm{s}bold_italic_s is a random vector:

𝐉𝒙=𝔼𝒔{∇𝐡(𝒔)𝚺−1∇𝐡(𝒔)T}+𝐉𝒔\mathbf{J}_{\bm{x}}=\mathbb{E}_{\bm{s}}\{\bm{\nabla}_{\mathbf{h}}(\bm{s})\bm{% \Sigma}^{-1}\bm{\nabla}_{\mathbf{h}}(\bm{s})^{T}\}+\mathbf{J}_{\bm{s}}bold_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { bold_∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_s ) bold_Σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_s ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } + bold_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (48)

which is the nonlinear extension of (23) — and the equivalent of the SNR matrix. This result shows that in the nonlinear case, the information obtained by the observation and priors are again additive; but this time, both depend on the source distribution. As a result, the model and prior effects are not separable in the nonlinear case.

By comparing these results with the linear case, we notice that statements similar to Lemma 2 exist in the nonlinear case, this time using the Jacobian of the nonlinear mixture.

4 Conclusion and future work

In this work we provided theoretical insights to help understanding of sensor fusion and selection in multimodal and multichannel systems. Grounded in information and estimation theory, we investigated linear and nonlinear signal mixtures contaminated by additive (Gaussian) noise. This is a recurrent problem in many applications, including biomedical applications where a physiological phenomenon can be monitored using multiple electrodes or using multiple modalities. A key aspect of this study was the exploration of the multichannel signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) matrix, which emerges as a critical tool in discerning the conditions under which sensor selection or fusion is either beneficial or redundant. The practical implications of these findings are substantial, as they guide the decision-making process in designing multichannel/multimodal systems.

In future research, these preliminary results can be extended from various perspectives. The channel/modality redundancy conditions obtained in Lemma 2 require further investigation, particularly for cases where 𝒙𝒙\bm{x}bold_italic_x and 𝒚𝒚\bm{y}bold_italic_y do not have equal lengths. The notion of the SNR matrix was instrumental in this work. Additional insights can be gained by studying the eigenstructure of the SNR matrix using singular value decomposition or by employing concentration ellipses [13, Sec. 2.4] to provide further understanding for using the CRLB in modality selection and fusion.

From the applied perspective, we can study the impact of the hereby studied ideas for problems such as lead selection and fusion for noninvasive fetal [6], and adult [10, 11] electrocardiography; or the problem of multimodal cardiac monitoring [7].
